Communist Party of the United States of America Records

The CPUSA bases its organizational structure on democratic centralism, a principle under which collectively decided policy decisions are binding for all members. Democratic centralism is designed to ensure unity in the will and actions of the membership and leadership. The National Convention is the root of authority in the Party; however, several national leadership bodies are responsible for directing and supervising the work of the Party between National Conventions. The records of these national leadership bodies comprise this subseries. Meeting minutes, audio recordings of individual meetings, correspondence, and reports make up the bulk of each body's records. The records of the Central Committee are the most extensive, spanning most of the 20th century. Highlights include a report on the expulsion of Earl Browder and reports from the Agitprop Department from the 1930s. Recordings of National Committee meetings are also quite extensive and span from the late 1950s to the 1990s. It should be noted that the official name of these bodies has not been consistent throughout the Party's history. As a result, the Central Committee is also referred to in CPUSA documentation as the National Committee while the Political Bureau is also referred to as the Political Committee and possibly as the National Board. For a more detailed description of the roles and responsibilities of each of these national leadership bodies, researchers may wish to consult various editions of the Constitution of the Communist Party of the United States of America.
